Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Towards New Scalable Stochastic Flow Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The process of clustering or partitioning of nodes within a graph is a fundamental task with applications in many areas ranging from social network analysis to chip design and from biological network analysis to the analysis of intelligence networks. This project seeks to explore and develop a new class of algorithms for graph clustering based on the principle of stochastic flows. Such algorithms have been used effectively on small scale biological networks and have been shown to be robust to noise effects. However, widespread utilization has been limited due to the lack of scalability of the algorithm and its inability, in its current form, to accommodate domain-specific constraints on clustering.

This exploratory project seeks to address these two limitations: First, it seeks to develop a novel approach for supporting flexible clustering in the context of stochastic flow clustering, allowing users to control the skew of the resulting clustering arrangement (e.g., to ensure balanced clusters), and allowing the nodes of a graph to participate in multiple clusters (so as to allow clusters to overlap). Second, it seeks to develop solutions that can scale to very large graphs (e.g. social networks, web graphs) through the innovative applications of graph sparsification and novel parallel algorithms on high performance systems. Open source implementation of the resulting a proof-of-concept solution will be distributed to the broader scientific community.

The scientific impact of this exploratory research agenda include the following: First, if one is successful in scaling up stochastic flow algorithms to web-scale datasets while retaining its many advantages, this would open up a viable robust and improved alternative to the current state-of-the art. Second, one can also employ stochastic flow clustering algorithms in a manner analogous to spectral methods on more traditional data sources (non-graphical), enabling more wide-spread use of flow clustering algorithms.

The broader impacts of the project include increased research-based training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in data analytics. Additional information about the project can be found at: http://www.cse.ohio-state.edu/~srini/EAGER11/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The process of clustering nodes within a graph is a fundamental task with applications in many areas ranging from social network analysis to chip design and from protein interaction analysis to disaster response.  This project sought to explore and develop a new class of algorithms for graph clustering based on the principle of stochastic flows (random walks). The major scientific (intellectual merit) outcomes include:

1. The development of novel stochastic flow algorithms for incorporating domain specific insights and constraints in the clustering process to control the skew of the resulting clustering arrangement and enabling a form of soft clustering allowing nodes of a graph to be a part of multiple clusters. The utility of said algorithm was evaluated on three real-world networks drawn from protein interaction data, social network data and chip design data.

2.  Scalable enhancements to existing stochastic flow algorithms were designed and evaluated on large scale social network data involving billions of edges and hundreds of millions of nodes. The novel enhancements involved the use of graph sparsification (reducing the number of edges to be processed) and the use of graph coarsening (simultaneously reducing the number of nodes and edges to be processed). The tradeoff between speedup and accuracy was carefully evaluated on real-world datasets drawn from social media sites and the new algorithms were found to be extremely effective when compared to extant solutions.

The main outcomes from a publication, training and outreach (broader impact) perspective include:

1. Two students were partially supported using this grant. One student completed a PhD Dissertation titled "Scalable Clustering of Modern Networks". This dissertation was recently acknowledged by the Association for Computing Machinery Special Interest Group on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining as an honorable mention finalist in the annual worldwide dissertation competition. The other student's dissertation is in progress.

2. The results from this research were disseminated in several ways -- publications in leading conferences and journals, invited talks given by the PI and elements of this research were discussed in a recent tutorial at an international conference. Above all, an important artifact was the software product resulting from this research which has been widely disseminated. This software artificat has found compelling use within the chip industry (a major manufacturer is an official licensee) and within the academic community for social science and bioinformatics research.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2013
Modified by: Srinivasan Parthasarathy

This project sought to explore and develop a new class of algorithms for graph clustering based on the principle of stochastic flows (random walks). The major scientific (intellectual merit) outcomes include: 1. The development of novel stochastic flow algorithms for incorporating domain specific insights and constraints in the clustering process to control the skew of the resulting clustering arrangement and enabling a form of soft clustering allowing nodes of a graph to be a part of multiple clusters. The utility of said algorithm was evaluated on three real-world networks drawn from protein interaction data, social network data and chip design data. 2. Scalable enhancements to existing stochastic flow algorithms were designed and evaluated on large scale social network data involving billions of edges and hundreds of millions of nodes. The novel enhancements involved the use of graph sparsification (reducing the number of edges to be processed) and the use of graph coarsening (simultaneously reducing the number of nodes and edges to be processed). The tradeoff between speedup and accuracy was carefully evaluated on real-world datasets drawn from social media sites and the new algorithms were found to be extremely effective when compared to extant solutions. The main outcomes from a publication, training and outreach (broader impact) perspective include: 1. Two students were partially supported using this grant. One student completed a PhD Dissertation titled "Scalable Clustering of Modern Networks". This dissertation was recently acknowledged by the Association for Computing Machinery Special Interest Group on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining as an honorable mention finalist in the annual worldwide dissertation competition. The other student's dissertation is in progress. 2. The results from this research were disseminated in several ways -- publications in leading conferences and journals, invited talks given by the PI and elements of this research were discussed in a recent tutorial at an international conference. Above all, an important artifact was the software product resulting from this research which has been widely disseminated. This software artificat has found compelling use within the chip industry (a major manufacturer is an official licensee) and within the academic community for social science and bioinformatics research.
